data.title: Vector support?
data.body:
As far as I know, Godot supports ONLY static images of the `png`/`jpg`/`jpeg` format. How about implementing support for vector formats? This would eliminate the blurring and pixel problems. In this way, the vector will always look good at all screen resolutions at any zoom level.

I'm not talking about replacing one format with another. I'm talking about additional implementation for those who need it.

data.title: no tween_complete signal is emit by method tween.interpolate_callback
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
ALL

**Issue description:**
func _on_tween_complete(obj, key, tween):
	print("free", obj, key)
	tween.queue_free()
	
func call_delay(delay, object, method, arg0=null,arg1=null,arg2=null,arg3=null,arg4=null):
	var tween = Tween.new()
	tween.interpolate_callback(object, delay, method, arg0, arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4)
	add_child(tween)
	tween.start()
	tween.connect("tween_complete", self, "_on_tween_complete", [tween])
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
_on_tween_complete will not call
there is no way to free the tween object

**Steps to reproduce:**


**Link to minimal example project:**

data.title: [Script] Primitive types should be in Mesh, not ArrayMesh
data.body:
Latest Godot:

I found primitive types must be accessed in `ArrayMesh` now, however they are in Mesh in C++, and it also makes more sense to access them here IMO.

data.title: The grid fades out in an empty project
data.body:
In latest Godot, Windows 10 64 bits

I just created an empty project, and noticed the grid is fading in a weird way:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/27153943-89d2bc18-5153-11e7-85db-abf66f570cc5.png)

It depends on the camera angle, sometimes the grid is fully visible, sometimes it disappears completely.

data.title: Scene-tiles for tilemaps
data.body:
Part of what was mentioned in #5965, though somewhat related to #3637 as well. Also, will obsolete all "Add scripts to tiles" issues if implemented. 

### Why put whole scenes in tilemaps? "We already have scene instancing for that!"

**TL;DR** - using instanced scenes instead of tiles in various places bloats the scene tree and makes for a bad workflow. Instancing scenes to replace certain tiles in `_ready()` is just a manual implementation of the feature which has been somewhat popular so far.

---

Unlike #9179, this time I can't say that scene instancing is hacky. Actually, what we currently have has worked for ages without having any problems. Sadly, the current workflow is a bit unwieldy...

As an example, here is how a typical Minilens [level](https://github.com/KOBUGE-Games/minilens/blob/eed8ef3325704e7ff9c94a2451de2783e2a5a087/levels/first_contact/level_11.tscn) looks like, shown alongside the scene tree:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5276727/27148519-43455e22-5149-11e7-83e5-149d31cfaa67.png)

The typical problem here is that it is hard to find a specific box, flower, bomb pickup, etc., unless you select it from the viewport. And if you want to move a part of the level slightly... you have to move all the respective boxes/flowers/pickups along.

As an additional bugger, you have to remember to turn on "use snap" and then "configure snap" to use the proper tile size. That, or calculate the positions of the various nodes by hand.

Some people have solved this problem by having some tiles which get replaced in `_ready()` with their real versions. This makes a slight performance hit on load times as well as being too much boilerplate. I think having it in core is going to ease things for a lot of people.

### Ok, let's say the workflow can be probably improved, what do you propose?

* Some tiles of the `TileSet` should be able to have a `PackedScene`.
* When a tile of such a scene type is encountered, we don't draw anything in its place, but add a separate node with the instance (which has owner = null, so that it won't be saved).
* If the instanced child does not extend CanvasItem, just spam the console with errors. Or maybe check if it has a `set_position` method, and call it.

Optional features:
* In case the child gets removed from the tree for whatever reason, we just do a `set_cell(x,y, -1)` behind the scenes.
* Provide a `move_cell(from_x, from_y, to_x, to_y)` / `move_cellv(from, to)`, which would move the instance, instead of recreating a new one at the other position. This might have an additional flag that would cause it not to call `set_position` on the child again.
* Allow scene tiles to also have a texture, so that they can be free to move around without leaving holes (note that this can be done by just having a Sprite as the root of the scene, but then it won't benefit from Tilemap's batching). This might somewhat conflict with the first optional feature.

data.title: Animations in TileMap
data.body:
Part of what was mentioned in #5965, putting as separate issue for maintainability.

### Why animations in tilemaps? "We already have AnimationPlayer for that!"

Yes, we do. Actually, we can already make animations with tilemaps, as evidenced by [Minilens](https://github.com/KOBUGE-Games/minilens/blob/eed8ef3325704e7ff9c94a2451de2783e2a5a087/main/level_holder.gd#L43-L45):
```gdscript
func _process(delta): # Move the acid
	acid_animation_pos = acid_animation_pos + delta
	if(acid_animation_pos > acid_animation_time):
		acid_animation_pos = acid_animation_pos - acid_animation_time
	level_tileset.tile_set_region(2, Rect2(64-64*acid_animation_pos/acid_animation_time,0,64,64))
```
Unfortunately, this is very hacky, and also forces update of _all_ quadrants, as opposed to just quadrants which have the animated tile.

### Ok, so what's the idea?

(terminology note: a `TileMap` is made up of **cells**. Each cell is of a specific type, know as a **tile**.)

After discussing the issue with @ArcFutahito on IRC, we agreed on the following idea:

* Tiles of the `TileSet` should be made animateable somehow (probably via `SpriteFrames`)
* The whole tilemap's animation should be turnable on/off, and probably it should have a speed parameter like `AnimationPlayer` and `AnimatedSprite` do. It might be useful to seek it as well.
* We don't need to be able to turn animation for a specific *cell* or *tile* on/off -- it is way too specific to be put in core, and performance would suffer as well (feel free to provide examples for when it might be useful)
* All cells with the same tile id would get the same frame at a given point in time; a cell added later would still get the same frame as other cells with the same tile.

---

About the implementation, I'm still not sure if we should keep cells with animations on separate canvas items, as to save some redraws. So, this is also something we might want to discuss.

data.title: Fix/improve TouchScreenButton (2.1)
data.body:
- Refactor touch acceptance logic so the same is used whether passby is enabled or not.
- Remove the check for visibility during input handling as it should never fail; instead using now an ERR_FAIL_COND() just in case since we have been checking for that so far.

Fixes #9159.

__NOTE;__ I've done this pretty quickly. It seems to be OK, but if @Danathus (as the issue reporter) and others could check, that'd be nice.

data.title: Use inline code for isinf with gcc versions <6.
data.body: Fixes #9166.

data.title: Fix/improve TouchScreenButton
data.body:
- Refactor touch acceptance logic so the same is used whether passby is enabled or not.
- Remove the check for visibility during input handling as it should never fail; instead using now an ERR_FAIL_COND() just in case since we have been checking for that so far.
- Fix cast to wrong InputEventScreenTouch when it should be InputEventScreenDrag.
- Replaced use of references by plain pointers for a more readable code and maybe a little performance gain.

data.title: Correct Image::blit_rect
data.body: #9156 shows a bug in copying a rectangular subsection of an image to a new image. This PR corrects the calculation of rectangles in `Image::blit_rect` that causes it.

data.title: Make toggle between thumbnail and list for file dialog on editor
data.body:
Both **thumbnail** and **list** button on file dialog can be turned off for now.
This will make sure to turn on one of them.

data.title: [master] Add Signals descriptions when they exist.
[2.1] Add Signals descriptions when they exist.
AudioServer has no way to get index from bus name
data.body:
*Bugsquad edit:* 
**Godot version:** Current master branch.

I noticed AudioServer has a way to get a bus name from an index, but no method to get a bus index from a bus name. This would be a helpful helper method to expose to gdscript.

data.title: Visual Scripting: User defined functions always return "Null"
data.body:
Arch Linux, Godot 3.0 master

**Issue description:**

User defined functions in Visual Script always return Null, even if a return value was specified. I have tested many different kinds of return values and never got anything back when calling the functions.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. create a node with a visual script
2. define a new functions and make it return a value
3. call the function and check its return value

**Link to minimal example project:**
Here is a minimal example project:
[vs_test.tar.gz](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1074323/vs_test.tar.gz)

data.title: [Suggestion] Add a limit parameter for .replace
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1.3

I'm creating a chatbox where I am converting text like `:joy:` -> to [img]res://joy.png[/img]

However, looking over the docs I was trying to limit the amount of smileys a player can use. While looking at the   GDScript's `String` class, the `.replace` method has no limit parameter   

Example:

> String replace( String what, String forwhat )
> Replace occurrences of a substring for different ones inside the string.

Proposed feature:

> String replace( String what, String forwhat, **int limit=-1**)
> Replace occurrences of a substring for different ones inside the string. 

This might have been suggested before but couldn't find anything. thanks for reading! 

e: -1 would be default, to replace all ofc or whatever. i think you guys get my idea :P

data.title: Visual lag with UWP
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows. Tested with both Godot 2.2 and 2.1.3(git)

**Issue description:**
There is a small delay between input and what is shown on the screen. It seems like the render is lagging behind (0.5sec maybe).
I know its not related with input because I can hear the sound fx when a key is pressed right away, it is the image that is delayed.

Tested with ANGLE and Godot in release mode for x64.

data.title: Added new "blend_rect" method as an alpha-aware blit_rect
data.body:
Implemented a new method which acts as "blit_rect" with alpha-blending, copying a rectangle on top of another rectangle using alpha-blending. 
I needed this implemented as a fast method for a pixel editor I work on and GDScript was too slow for this.
I would add a similar function for 3.0 as well but currently the compilation for master seems broken.

Here is a simple example project: 
[blittestalfa.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1073781/blittestalfa.zip)

**Steps to reproduce:**

an error appears:
core/math/math_funcs.h: In static member function 'static bool Math::is_inf(double)':
core/math/math_funcs.h:123:21: error: 'isinf' was not declared in this scope

data.title: Refactor layer_mask to collision_layer
data.body:
The name `layer_mask` can be confusing, especially in the inspector it usually displays below Collision category as "Layers" and another as "Mask". So it's unclear if `layer_mask` refers to `collision_layer` or `collision_mask`.

![editor](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26753932/27115974-67bf6be0-50f8-11e7-9280-e2390aa794f4.png)

Current situation:

| Area(2D)               | PhysicsBody(2D)         | TileMap                 | RayCast(2D)        |
| ---------------------- | ----------------------- | ----------------------- | ------------------ |
| collision_mask         | collision_mask          | collision_mask          | -                 |
| set_collision_mask     | set_collision_mask      | set_collision_mask      | -                 |
| collision_layer**s**   | collision_layer         | collision_layer**s**    | layer_mask         |
| set_layer_mask         | set_collision_layer     | set_collision_layer     | set_layer_mask     |

| Physics(2D)Server       |
| ----------------------- |
| area_set_collision_mask |
| body_set_collision_mask |
| area_set_layer_mask     |
| body_set_layer_mask     |

@bojidar-bg suggested that I use `collision_layer`.

data.title: Dictionaries don't respect insertion order
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
Dictionaries don't respect insertion order, but 0a59c3c3a6a8c13a5c82d59d9587fca31f900604 claimed they should.

**Steps to reproduce:**
```
var dict = {"C": 1, "B": 2, "A": 3}
print(dict)
(A:3), (B:2), (C:1)
for k in dict:
	print(k)
C
A
B
```

data.title: renamed occurances of ColorRamp with Gradient
data.body: ColorRamp got renamed to Gradient recently, reduz missed some occurances though.

data.title: TouchScreenButtons ignore Shape when Passby Press is enabled
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Found on Windows & Android w/ Godot 2.1.3 stable.

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When passby press is enabled, TouchScreenButtons ignore shapes. This is pretty clear in the code -- in `TouchScreenButton::_input()`, `shape` is only referenced in the block where `passby_press` is `false`.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1) Create a TouchScreenButton with a Normal image set.
2) Give it a Shape that should be easy to touch, with an area expanding beyond the image dimensions.
3) Wire something up so that you know when the button is successfully pressed.
4) Make sure Passby Press is disabled.
5) Run/play to confirm that you can press the button successfully, touching anywhere within the Shape boundaries.
6) Enable Passby Press.
7) Run/play again and observe that you can only press the button by touching the Normal image, not by hitting within the Shape boundaries.

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
